section.title: although, but, however, nevertheless
section.sectiontitle: Use all of these linking words to show that what you are saying is surprising or unexpected in relation to something else you know to be true. Use but to join two clauses with contrasting information (clause + but + clause).
section.text1: She was late. We decided to wait for her.
section.text1a: She was late but we decided to wait for her.
section.text2: But is not usually used to begin a sentence.
section.text2a: He fell over but he didn't hurt himself.
section.sectiontitle2: Although comes before a clause. Use either Although + clause, clause or clause, + although + clause.
section.text3a: Although she was half an hour late, they decided to wait a bit longer.
section.text4a: They decided to wait a bit longer, although she was half an hour late.

section.title: although, but, however, nevertheless
section.sectiontitle: Though can be used as a shortened form of although. It is more common in informal speech.
section.text1a: Though I was angry with him, I didn't say anything.
section.text2a: Though it was raining, he didn't take an umbrella.
section.sectiontitle2: Use even though to emphasise a contrast.
section.text3a: Even though I was very angry with him, I didn't say anything.
section.text4a: Even though it was pouring with rain, he didn't take an umbrella.

section.title: although, but, however, nevertheless
section.sectiontitle: Use however, or nevertheless, to start a sentence that contains information contrasting with the previous sentence.
section.text1a: She was half an hour late. However, they decided to wait a bit longer.
section.text2a: The shop was very crowded. However, we pushed our way in.
section.text3a: Your work has not been of a very high standard recently. Nevertheless, I am still going to give you a 5 per cent pay increase.
section.text4a: She was very tired. Nevertheless, she went to the party.
